Author: falsestprophet
Content: I bet Paul Graham could make a lot more working for McKinsey than at Y Combinator. These folks have one hell of a racket.

Author: ratsbane
Content:
Yes. Good observation. I wonder how much of it is environmental? As I grow older I'm thinking more about how to show other people how to do the things I figured out when I was younger and how to organize groups of people to get things done on a broader scale.

I don't want to stop thinking like I did when I was younger, though. It's important to continue learning things, which probably means paying some attention to lower-level topics.

Today is my birthday. [argh]

Author: falsestprophet
Content: They pay a lot more than $50k per year and charge a lot more than $250 per hour.

Author: simen
Content: So modern it makes you do the compiler's job of marking your tail calls.

Author: NickSmith
Content:
"OOP to me means only messaging, local retention and protection and hiding of state-process, and extreme late-binding of all things. It can be done in Smalltalk and in LISP. There are possibly other systems in which this is possible, but I'm not aware of them."... Alan Kay 2003

http://userpage.fu-berlin.de/~ram/pub/pub_jf47ht25Ht/doc_kay...

Author: sanj
Content: I've always felt that having childcare nearby is important.  Employees age.  They have kids (yay!).  And having something nearby can keep everyone motivated and employed longer.

Author: staunch
Content: Hah. I was just talking about this with a friend days ago. I live in Japan now. I love to sit and read alone in restaurants/cafes. I've become so accustomed to not understanding most of what's being said around me that when someone is speaking English within earshot it's ridiculously distracting. Even when I can't make out what they're saying the familiar sounds cause my brain to go nuts (in a background process) trying to interpret.

Author: iamwil
Content:
I thought his style of presentation had much to improve on, but it shed new light on what he intended with smalltalk. Apparently, encapsulation was only really one small part of his whole idea.

http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=78364

I think this particular post sums up his ideas in his presentation. Also, watch it with 1997 in mind. That's why he rails against MS so much.
